prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 283Ghz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is one of 8 setups aimed at covering the bottom half of Band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our lines are expected to be very broad in the observed space and we wish to cover the maximum possible bandpass so we are requesting the lowest spectral resolution. We are attempting to detect a line, but for simplicity have set up the correlator in continuum mode.
We request the lowest possible angular resolution to maximize sensitivity.

Based on Capak et al. 2015, we expect these sources to have a peak CII line flux of 9mJy and a sigma of 120kms (0.15GHz window for the line peak). To detect a 9mJy peak line at an SNR=10 in a 0.15GHz bandwidth we require a continuu, sensitivity of 120uJy.
We are trying to have continious spectral coverage of the bottom half of band 7 and selected 8 frequencies in the 8 science goals to give us such coverage.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The recent discovery of a large population of very massive galaxies with photometric redshifts z~5-6 in surveys such as CANDELS and SPLASH is difficult to reconcile with the predictions of hierarchical merging. The largest observational uncertainties in these analyses lie in the possibility of catastrophic errors in photometric redshift determination, particularly because a z < 2 Balmer break may be easily confused with a z~5-6 Lyman break. Spectroscopic followup observations are both expensive and difficult, due to a combination of faint sources and weak Ly$\alpha$ emission in high-redshift star-forming galaxies. We propose observations to conclusively determine the redshift to five of the best-measured galaxies with high photometric redshifts and stellar masses in SPLASH, allowing a definitive determination of whether these galaxies are indeed impossibly massive within the hierarchical merging paradigm.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Spitzer Science Center, California Institute of Technology
Department of Physics, California at Riverside, University of
